newsitem.title: USA: CSCE coffee called to open 0.50 cent higher.
newsitem.headline: CSCE coffee called to open 0.50 cent higher.

text.p: CSCE coffee futures were called to open 0.50 cent higher Tuesday as traders expect the market to follow through on Monday's firmer close.

New York arabicas erased early losses and ended mostly higher in light trading Monday. September arabicas settled up 2.25 cents at 180.20 cents a lb after ranging from 181.00 to 175.00 cents. Active December ended 1.10 cents higher at 162.95 cents, while the back months closed up 0.90 to down 0.60 cent.
September/December widened to 17.25 cents compared with 16.10 cents at the close Friday. December/March 1998 stretched to 15.95 cents versus 15.75 cents the previous session.
Technically, traders pegged September resistance at 182.50 cents and then 187.00 cents. Support was seen at 175.00 cents, followed by 172.50-172.00 cents.
After Monday's close, CSCE reported exchange-certified coffee stocks rose by 457 60-kg bags as of August 15, to 92,428 bags. An additional 5,500 bags of coffee were pending grading.
On the fundamental front, truck drivers in Colombia's main transport union declared a strike at the Colombian port of Buenaventura to protest low freight rates.
But sources at the port, which handles 60 percent of Colombia's trade, including coffee exports, said operations were not affected.

London robusta futures were higher early Tuesday in switch-dominated trade. LIFFE November rose $42 at the midday break, to $1,525, after ranging from $1,530 to $1,485. Spot September was up $39, to $1,500.
